Award.AwardTitle: Development of Native Language Preference: Behavioral and Physiological Indices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Previous research shows that within the first year of life infants are able to distinguish their native language from a language they have never heard before. In fact, they prefer to listen to their native language over an unfamiliar language. In the first component of this research, native language preference--measured using listening time or heart rate measures--will be used to capture how much and how well each infant takes in linguistic input that is available to her. In addition, by following infants with and without a preference for their native language longitudinally, the project aims to determine whether a preference measure can be used to index speech and language development later in life. The relationship between native language preference and speech and language development later in life will be investigated for English- as well as Spanish-learning infants. The final component of the research will determine what information infants rely on to distinguish their native language from a similar, yet unfamiliar language. Infants' listening time to re-synthesized native and non-native language when different elements of the speech--consonants and vowels, or the rhythm and intonation--are removed will help address this question.

This work seeks to apply basic research on the abilities infants in the first year of life towards developing a tool for early identification of children with speech and language delays. By tracing the relationship of native language preference that can be measured anytime within the first 15-months of life and later language development, this research may provide insight into why some children seem to have difficulties with language acquisition. Further, by testing Spanish-learning infants as well we are laying the foundation for future research with bilingual infants learning Spanish and English. This is critical given that Spanish is spoken in about 40-50% of the homes in certain parts of the US. Finally, the research undertaken in this project will provide educational opportunities for a graduate student and several undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was built on the finding from typically-developing infants with normal hearing that newborns show a very subtle preference for listening to their native language. We hypothesized that an infant’s preference for listening to her native language is indicative of her intake of the language input that is available to her.  Thus, for any theory of acquisition where the infant plays an active role in the process of acquisition, an infant’s intake is a mediating variable between linguistic input and language development.  Specifically, a measure of native language preference has the potential to predict the variability in infants’ linguistic abilities. Thus, one goal of this project was to compare and contrast infants' preference for listening to their native language with their preference for looking at faces talking in their native language.

We tested 4- and 8-month-old monolingual English- and bilingual Spanish- and English-learning infants’ preference for listening to English vs Spanish and compared it to their preference for looking at a silent video of a face speaking English vs. Spanish. Our results show that infants’ preference for looking as well as listening to their native language is driven by their language experience – only monolingual English- not bilingual infants show a preference for English over Spanish; bilingual infants who had exposure to both, listen to both to the same extent. Further, this preference emerges first in the visual modality.

To prefer their native language over another language, infants have to first discriminate the two. Another goal of this project was to determine what information infants rely on in order to distinguish their native language from other languages. Specifically, we tested whether infants rely on the distribution of consonants and vowel, or their native language prosody – i.e., the intonation and the rhythm to distinguish their native language from a similar, yet non-native language. Our results show that infants’ ability to distinguish American English and German develops between 5- and 7-months of age. Additionally, when the original intonation is replaced by a monotone, 7-month-olds fail to distinguish the two languages. Thus, intonation, not the distribution of consonants or vowels, or the rhythm, is necessary for infants’ discrimination of their native language, American English, and a similar, yet non-native language, German.

Research on this project has provided a developmental perspective on language development in infants learning English, as well as Spanish. Recent US Census data indicate that Spanish is spoken in as many as 40% of the families in certain areas (e.g. in LA county). Further, through parent outreach at schools and daycares as well as the development of web resources, this project has provided an excellent opportunity to disseminate information about the language acquisition process to English- & Spanish-speaking families participating in the studies. Further, this project has supported two doctoral students, both first generation college students, as well as several undergraduate students, including underrepresented minority students. In the future, by integrating basic research on behavioral and physiological indices of infant attention to language, we hope to be able to develop a clinical tool that can be applied for early identification of children with language delays.
